jmemsys.h

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 /*
00002  * jmemsys.h
00003  *
00004  * Copyright (C) 1992-1997, Thomas G. Lane.
00005  * This file is part of the Independent JPEG Group's software.
00006  * For conditions of distribution and use, see the accompanying README file.
00007  *
00008  * This include file defines the interface between the system-independent
00009  * and system-dependent portions of the JPEG memory manager.  No other
00010  * modules need include it.  (The system-independent portion is jmemmgr.c;
00011  * there are several different versions of the system-dependent portion.)
00012  *
00013  * This file works as-is for the system-dependent memory managers supplied
00014  * in the IJG distribution.  You may need to modify it if you write a
00015  * custom memory manager.  If system-dependent changes are needed in
00016  * this file, the best method is to #ifdef them based on a configuration
00017  * symbol supplied in jconfig.h, as we have done with USE_MSDOS_MEMMGR
00018  * and USE_MAC_MEMMGR.
00019  */
00020 
00024 
00025 
00026 /* Short forms of external names for systems with brain-damaged linkers. */
00027 
00028 #ifdef NEED_SHORT_EXTERNAL_NAMES
00029 #define jpeg_get_small      jGetSmall
00030 #define jpeg_free_small     jFreeSmall
00031 #define jpeg_get_large      jGetLarge
00032 #define jpeg_free_large     jFreeLarge
00033 #define jpeg_mem_available  jMemAvail
00034 #define jpeg_open_backing_store jOpenBackStore
00035 #define jpeg_mem_init       jMemInit
00036 #define jpeg_mem_term       jMemTerm
00037 #endif /* NEED_SHORT_EXTERNAL_NAMES */
00038 
00039 
00040 /*
00041  * These two functions are used to allocate and release small chunks of
00042  * memory.  (Typically the total amount requested through jpeg_get_small is
00043  * no more than 20K or so; this will be requested in chunks of a few K each.)
00044  * Behavior should be the same as for the standard library functions malloc
00045  * and free; in particular, jpeg_get_small must return NULL on failure.
00046  * On most systems, these ARE malloc and free.  jpeg_free_small is passed the
00047  * size of the object being freed, just in case it's needed.
00048  * On an 80x86 machine using small-data memory model, these manage near heap.
00049  */
00050 
00051 EXTERN(void *) jpeg_get_small JPP((j_common_ptr cinfo, size_t sizeofobject));
00052 EXTERN(void) jpeg_free_small JPP((j_common_ptr cinfo, void * object,
00053                   size_t sizeofobject));
00054 
00055 /*
00056  * These two functions are used to allocate and release large chunks of
00057  * memory (up to the total free space designated by jpeg_mem_available).
00058  * The interface is the same as above, except that on an 80x86 machine,
00059  * far pointers are used.  On most other machines these are identical to
00060  * the jpeg_get/free_small routines; but we keep them separate anyway,
00061  * in case a different allocation strategy is desirable for large chunks.
00062  */
00063 
00064 EXTERN(void FAR *) jpeg_get_large JPP((j_common_ptr cinfo,
00065                        size_t sizeofobject));
00066 EXTERN(void) jpeg_free_large JPP((j_common_ptr cinfo, void FAR * object,
00067                   size_t sizeofobject));
00068 
00069 /*
00070  * The macro MAX_ALLOC_CHUNK designates the maximum number of bytes that may
00071  * be requested in a single call to jpeg_get_large (and jpeg_get_small for that
00072  * matter, but that case should never come into play).  This macro is needed
00073  * to model the 64Kb-segment-size limit of far addressing on 80x86 machines.
00074  * On those machines, we expect that jconfig.h will provide a proper value.
00075  * On machines with 32-bit flat address spaces, any large constant may be used.
00076  *
00077  * NB: jmemmgr.c expects that MAX_ALLOC_CHUNK will be representable as type
00078  * size_t and will be a multiple of sizeof(align_type).
00079  */
00080 
00081 #ifndef MAX_ALLOC_CHUNK     /* may be overridden in jconfig.h */
00082 #define MAX_ALLOC_CHUNK  1000000000L
00083 #endif
00084 
00085 /*
00086  * This routine computes the total space still available for allocation by
00087  * jpeg_get_large.  If more space than this is needed, backing store will be
00088  * used.  NOTE: any memory already allocated must not be counted.
00089  *
00090  * There is a minimum space requirement, corresponding to the minimum
00091  * feasible buffer sizes; jmemmgr.c will request that much space even if
00092  * jpeg_mem_available returns zero.  The maximum space needed, enough to hold
00093  * all working storage in memory, is also passed in case it is useful.
00094  * Finally, the total space already allocated is passed.  If no better
00095  * method is available, cinfo->mem->max_memory_to_use - already_allocated
00096  * is often a suitable calculation.
00097  *
00098  * It is OK for jpeg_mem_available to underestimate the space available
00099  * (that'll just lead to more backing-store access than is really necessary).
00100  * However, an overestimate will lead to failure.  Hence it's wise to subtract
00101  * a slop factor from the true available space.  5% should be enough.
00102  *
00103  * On machines with lots of virtual memory, any large constant may be returned.
00104  * Conversely, zero may be returned to always use the minimum amount of memory.
00105  */
00106 
00107 EXTERN(long) jpeg_mem_available JPP((j_common_ptr cinfo,
00108                      long min_bytes_needed,
00109                      long max_bytes_needed,
00110                      long already_allocated));
00111 
00112 
00113 /*
00114  * This structure holds whatever state is needed to access a single
00115  * backing-store object.  The read/write/close method pointers are called
00116  * by jmemmgr.c to manipulate the backing-store object; all other fields
00117  * are private to the system-dependent backing store routines.
00118  */
00119 
00120 #define TEMP_NAME_LENGTH   64   /* max length of a temporary file's name */
00121 
00122 
00123 #ifdef USE_MSDOS_MEMMGR     /* DOS-specific junk */
00124 
00125 typedef unsigned short XMSH;    /* type of extended-memory handles */
00126 typedef unsigned short EMSH;    /* type of expanded-memory handles */
00127 
00128 typedef union {
00129   short file_handle;        /* DOS file handle if it's a temp file */
00130   XMSH xms_handle;      /* handle if it's a chunk of XMS */
00131   EMSH ems_handle;      /* handle if it's a chunk of EMS */
00132 } handle_union;
00133 
00134 #endif /* USE_MSDOS_MEMMGR */
00135 
00136 #ifdef USE_MAC_MEMMGR       /* Mac-specific junk */
00137 #include <Files.h>
00138 #endif /* USE_MAC_MEMMGR */
00139 
00140 
00141 typedef struct backing_store_struct * backing_store_ptr;
00142 
00143 typedef struct backing_store_struct {
00144   /* Methods for reading/writing/closing this backing-store object */
00145   JMETHOD(void, read_backing_store, (j_common_ptr cinfo,
00146                      backing_store_ptr info,
00147                      void FAR * buffer_address,
00148                      long file_offset, long byte_count));
00149   JMETHOD(void, write_backing_store, (j_common_ptr cinfo,
00150                       backing_store_ptr info,
00151                       void FAR * buffer_address,
00152                       long file_offset, long byte_count));
00153   JMETHOD(void, close_backing_store, (j_common_ptr cinfo,
00154                       backing_store_ptr info));
00155 
00156   /* Private fields for system-dependent backing-store management */
00157 #ifdef USE_MSDOS_MEMMGR
00158   /* For the MS-DOS manager (jmemdos.c), we need: */
00159   handle_union handle;      /* reference to backing-store storage object */
00160   char temp_name[TEMP_NAME_LENGTH]; /* name if it's a file */
00161 #else
00162 #ifdef USE_MAC_MEMMGR
00163   /* For the Mac manager (jmemmac.c), we need: */
00164   short temp_file;      /* file reference number to temp file */
00165   FSSpec tempSpec;      /* the FSSpec for the temp file */
00166   char temp_name[TEMP_NAME_LENGTH]; /* name if it's a file */
00167 #else
00168   /* For a typical implementation with temp files, we need: */
00169   FILE * temp_file;     /* stdio reference to temp file */
00170   char temp_name[TEMP_NAME_LENGTH]; /* name of temp file */
00171 #endif
00172 #endif
00173 } backing_store_info;
00174 
00175 
00176 /*
00177  * Initial opening of a backing-store object.  This must fill in the
00178  * read/write/close pointers in the object.  The read/write routines
00179  * may take an error exit if the specified maximum file size is exceeded.
00180  * (If jpeg_mem_available always returns a large value, this routine can
00181  * just take an error exit.)
00182  */
00183 
00184 EXTERN(void) jpeg_open_backing_store JPP((j_common_ptr cinfo,
00185                       backing_store_ptr info,
00186                       long total_bytes_needed));
00187 
00188 
00189 /*
00190  * These routines take care of any system-dependent initialization and
00191  * cleanup required.  jpeg_mem_init will be called before anything is
00192  * allocated (and, therefore, nothing in cinfo is of use except the error
00193  * manager pointer).  It should return a suitable default value for
00194  * max_memory_to_use; this may subsequently be overridden by the surrounding
00195  * application.  (Note that max_memory_to_use is only important if
00196  * jpeg_mem_available chooses to consult it ... no one else will.)
00197  * jpeg_mem_term may assume that all requested memory has been freed and that
00198  * all opened backing-store objects have been closed.
00199  */
00200 
00201 EXTERN(long) jpeg_mem_init JPP((j_common_ptr cinfo));
00202 EXTERN(void) jpeg_mem_term JPP((j_common_ptr cinfo));
